docs.lead_paragraph: His workout coming to a close, Ramon Martinez decided it was time to show Boston a little something extra. ''I let one go a little, but I know I can do better,'' Martinez said yesterday after agreeing to a minor league contract with the Red Sox that reunites him with his younger brother, Pedro.
docs.abstract: Pitcher Ramon Martinez, older brother of Pedro Martinez, signs minor league contract with Boston Red Sox (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a happy accident of timing that with James Cagney, the actor, again prominent in the news, a letter from George Toporcer broke a silence that had been allowed to endure too many years. Jim Cagney is famous for many talents, including the ability to do more with a grapefruit than Luther Burbank, but probably his proudest boast is that when he was growing up in Yorkville on the East Side of Manhattan, he played sandlot baseball with his neighbor, Specs Toporcer. Called Specs because of the glasses he wore from early boyhood, Toporcer went directly from the sandlots to the major leagues without even a hitch in high school ball. From 1921 to 1928 he played on the St. Louis Cardinals' infield, the first bespectacled infielder in the majors. After that he played for and managed teams in the minors, was farm director for the Red Sox and field director for the White Sox before going blind in 1951. After that, he turned to writing and lecturing, doing radio and television.

docs.lead_paragraph: BASEBALL'S annual flesh market opened yesterday with Dave Winfield and Don Sutton, as expected, the choice pieces of merchandise but not the most widely coveted. That distinction went to Dave W. Roberts, a .240 hitter who played all over for the Texas Rangers, and Jim Dwyer, a utility outfielder with the Boston Red Sox whose lifetime batting average is .250. Negotiation rights to Roberts were claimed by 12 teams plus the Rangers, and to Dwyer by 11 plus the Red Sox. Besides the San Diego Padres, who have employed him for eight years, 10 clubs declared their intention of dickering with Winfield, and 10 spoke up for Sutton, who is through as a pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Red Sox have not even played a game and they are already beating the Yankees. The Yankees' two-game split with the Devil Rays in Japan means that the Red Sox are one game up on the Yankees in the loss column going into tonight's opener in Baltimore. Folks in New England are pretty happy about this. It's a sickness, this contempt for all things pinstripe here in the Hardball Hub of the universe. Red Sox fans are forever jealous of the Yankees' success. There's a great deal of championship envy.
docs.abstract: Dan Shaughnessy Baseball Preview 2004 column discusses Boston Red Sox, which look to repair damage from American League Championship Series loss to rival New York Yankees in 2003; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ted Williams took his hands off the walker and danced a little jig. ''I'm pretty good,'' said Williams, the Hall of Famer, who was attending his first spring training game in several years yesterday in Clearwater, Fla. ''I can't see as well as I like, so, as a result, I lose a little balance. That's why I have to use this.''
docs.abstract: Baseball hall of famer Ted Williams visits Boston Red Sox spring training camp; photo (S)
